title: voters split over tory mp
story: Bury South voters react to Christian Wakefords defection: We should have a by-electionBury South MP Christian Wakeford has defected to the Labour Party just moments before Boris Johnson arrived in the House of Commons for Prime Ministers Questions Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByPaul Byrne:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A Conservative MP has defected to the Labour Party, accusing Boris Johnson of being incapable of offering the leadership the country deserves.Bury South MP Christian Wakeford, who was elected in , had been one of seven Tory MPs to publicly express no confidence in the Prime Minister.In a letter, he wrote: You and the Conservative Party as a whole have shown themselves incapable of offering the leadership and government this country deserves.The announcement came just moments before the PM took to the floor for Prime Ministeraposs Questions. Labour leader Keir Starmer said: I would like to welcome Christian Wakeford to the Labour Party. He has always put the people of Bury South first.But Health Secretary Sajid Javid told Sky News: “I feel sorry for the people of Bury South. I think a by-election would be welcome… I think Christian should be happy with a by-election”. He added: “They’ve got an MP who’s changed his affiliation without their permission”. Labour has indicated there will not be a by-election. So what do the voters of Bury South think  We spoke to them.  In the town of Prestwich, which sits in the Bury South constituency, there was a mixed response today to Christian Wakeford’s defection from Tory to Labour. Sham Raja, , said: “It’s so shameful. He signed up to be a Conservative MP. It’s disgraceful, he was elected under the Conservative banner.“There are lots of small businesses struggling at the moment and he’s said nothing about this. Boris Johnson was the only guy to bring us out of Europe and get Brexit done.“I think he should step down as an MP andhe wants to be a Labour MP, he should apply to be one. “He’s not won on a Labour  and he should take it upon himself to step down.” Jeremy Burtles, , said: “There should be another election – you can’t just switch. If you want to change parties, you need to step down. “You always vote for the party you want in charge so I think it’s ridiculous to switch all of a sudden. “If you’re going to change your view, you should just step down.” And Hazel Donnelly, , said: “I don’t think it was very good at all, he shouldn’t be allowed to do that.  “It won’t change the way I vote because I am a Conservative. “I don’t think it’s a big deal what Boris did - there are much worse things that have happened recently. “There should be certain rules with these things. I think he has broken a rule but there are more important things going on at the moment.” But Barry Humphries, , backed the MPaposs decision. He said: “Good for him, I think he’s doing what’s right for him and he’s standing up for what he believes in.” And Ifkan Ahmed, , added: “I’ve always been happy with him. I think these days it’s okay to change your policies. “He has been very good for our area and I’m happy with what he’s done. It doesn’t matter to me that he has changed.”  Vickie Stone, , said: “If he wants to do it because of Boris Johnson then I think that’s fair enough. “If he doesn’t agree with the way Boris is handling the situation then that’s up to him. “I’m more bothered about the leadership, I’m worried about who is going to replace Borisit ends up going that way.” In Radclfe, the centre of the constituency, the MPaposs office, painted in true-blue Tory colours, was shuttered. Outside on the street, ex-Labour and current Tory voter Mavis Leach said: Well, Iaposm surprised. Are there others doing it, as well, getting out of a sinking ship before it goes down  Mrs Leach, who said she disavowed Labour because of a dislike for former leader Jeremy Corbyn, said Boris Johnson should stay on as Prime Minister.I know heaposs done wrong, done a lot of things wrong, she said. Boris has done a lot of things. We know that. But I think heaposs done a good job in other things,bringing the vaccinations in, and weaposre in a good place for that. Another local, Jonathan Boston, a Labour supporter, said Mr Wakefordaposs change in loyalty is really good news. Presumably, itaposs all to do with partygate, he said, referring to allegations of lockdown-busting parties within No , though a Labour spokesman has since said talks with Mr Wakeford began before the scandal hit. Mr Boston said: From what one hears, all the MPs have had millions of emails from constituents saying, aposItaposs terrible and heaposs got to go,apos so I donapost think any Tory voter, even in Radclfe, or Bury South or whatever, would be surprised at .probably the first of many, I would have thought, especially the newer MPs. I think a lot of the newer ones will do a similar thing. Meanwhile, Chris Holland said he rated Mr Wakeford as a local MP but had not voted for him. He said: Iaposve never voted Tory and I never would do. Iaposve messaged him a few times and he has got back to me. To me, heaposs not been doing too bad. Iaposd rather have a Labourthan a Tory. David Collins, who runs Marieaposs Coffee Shop, a stoneaposs throw from Mr Wakefordaposs constituency office, said: I probably wouldnapost vote for either of them anyway, Labour or Conservative. Theyaposre all as bad as each other. They all promise theyaposre going to do things and none of it ever materialises, does it  You wouldnapost think you were able to jump ship halfway through, would you   Tory voter Joan Humphreys said she feels like her tick at the ballot box has now been wasted. She said: I feel like going down there and saying, aposRight. I want to withdraw it.apos If he wants to become Labour, and he wants to support Labouraposs policies, we should have a by-election and see what the people say. If Boris had held his hands up at the beginning, people would have been far more forgiving about it, but heaposs not. But who are you going to have instead of Boris  I canapost see anybody . title: i survived 911 didnt discuss
story: I survived   - but didnt discuss it until my kids were taught it at schoolLisa Ridd was just  when two planes crashed into the Twin Towers on  September  - but for years, she didnt talk about it. But when her eldest child learned about the attacks at school, she faced up to her traumaLisa was just  when two planes crashed into the Twin TowersByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman who survived   has revealed she couldnapost look at photos of the attack for over a decade after it happened. Lisa Ridd was just  when two planes plunged into the World Trade Centre in New York on  September, . She was just yards from the Twin Towers when the planes hit - and recalls she originally thought the fuss around her was down to a parade nearby. Speaking to FEMAIL, Lisa said she only realised the true horror of what was happening when she saw a plane flying towards her. She recalled: Somebody said something about a bomb I thought Thataposs ridiculous, but quickly the older, more seasoned people on the trading floor told me to get off the phone - we are evacuating. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here After coming out onto the street, Lisa and hundreds of others started running as they saw the second plane heading for the North Tower. Somehow amid the chaos, she managed to find her sister who also worked in the World Trade Centre, and retreated to her apartment for safety. Although she survived the massacre, her best friend Lindsay, who worked on the th floor of the South Tower, did not. The pair had made friends four years earlier while studying at university in Massachusetts. According to Lisa, Lindsay was the biggest light in the room. But Lisa didnapost find out her best friendaposs fate until days after the attack, while she was recovering from the shock at her parentsapos house in Virginia.  As more stories emerged of survivors being pulled from the rubble, Lisa became convinced Lindsay would be one of them. For days she continued to call Lindsayaposs phone, willing her to pick up. But on  September when Lindsayaposs mum called to discuss her daughteraposs funeral arrangements, it sunk in for Lisa that her university pal was gone. Over the next few months, Lisa was offered counselling at work to process the trauma of being caught up in the terror attack, but she refused it. In fact, she recalls she avoided the topic entirely.  For the next decade, she couldnapost read about the attacks in the newspaper, look at photos of the Twin Towers or talk about what sheaposd lived through. While she suppressed her memories, Lisa met her now-husband and had three children, aged , six and two. But when her eldest child came home one day and asked her about  , Lisa realised she needed to make peace with her trauma. I was like aposOkay I guess I need to tell my kids my storyaposapos, she said. Since sitting her children down to tell them about her experience, Lisa has also gone back to the World Trade Centre and spent time at the memorial to the victims of  . She said: You have no idea when you see photos how powerful it is. There are holes that will never be filled up. All you can hear is the water rushing through, water is so therapeutic anyway and the way they designed it it feels like cleansing an endless cycle of energy. All of your senses are just alive and I really could not think of a more beautul way to memorialise that spot. Lisa has also appeared in a documentary about the attacks, Memory Box: Echoes of   in which she tells her story.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcShe believes speaking about it on TV has further helped her process her trauma. She said: Itaposs not a story that belongs to just me, itaposs a story that deserves to be passed down for future generations and I would say itaposs probably unlucky to be part of history in that way but thataposs the reality.Memory Box: Echoes of   is available on Sky and NOW TVRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World Trade Center  attacks" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i uncovered family secret after
story: I uncovered family secret after taking home DNA test to find my biological dadKristin Shoonveld, , donated her eggs in , hoping to help a couple have a child. She thought little more of it until a home DNA kit she took in  revealed something incredibleKristin and Parker met just before the pandemicByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsA woman discovered a son she never knew she had after receiving results from a home DNA kit. Kristin Shoonveld, who is adopted, bought a test in autumn of  in the hope she might find out more about her biological father. Twenty-five years earlier, Kristin, now  donated her eggs in the hope sheaposd be able to give someone  a baby - but she hadnapost thought much about it. But after receiving her results from a andMe DNA test, the special needs worker from Indiana in the US saw that she had a son listed on the database. She told PEOPLE magazine she thought it was a mistake at first, having never carried a child of her own. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But after clicking on his profile, she was shocked to see the young man looked like her. And he had joined the  looking for his biological mother. Although she never had kids of her own, Kristin met Nick, a then nine-year-old boy with Down syndrome, while she was working in an SEN school. She instantly took Nick under her wing and looked out for him. Before long, she met Nickaposs mum, Grace, and the pair got on well. Sadly, Grace was diagnosed with lung cancer and became very unwell. While she was sick, Kristin took on more responsibility for Nick until Grace tragically passed away.  After she died in January , Kristin was there for Nick as sheaposd always been, but she became concerned about his dad, Brian. Kristin said: I was just one of many people who were really worried about how Brian and Nick were going to manoeuver through le, she says. I was mostly worried about them just being just overwhelmed with grief. As Kristin spent more time with Brian, the pair fell in love and married in . That same year, she officially adopted Nick. The adoption was what spurred her on to find out more about her own biological family - and before long, sheaposd found her biological mother. But, still without answers about her father, she took a DNA test in the hope she might find him. After making the incredible discovery about her son, Parker Erickson, Kristin reached out to him and the pair arranged to meet. It was just instant love, she said. Parker, from Santa Cruz in Calornia, found out he was conceived via egg donor when he was . After meeting his biological mother for the first time, he said it was instantly easy to love each other. And Kristinaposs son Nick was similarly thrilled to meet Parker, telling Kristin he always wanted a brother. Kristin said: Weaposve established a relationship thataposs going to last the rest of our lives. title: boy left teeth nose after
story: Boy left with teeth in his nose after gruesome accident on hotel water slideWARNING: DISTRESSING IMAGES Stunned mum Kelly Grfiths from Bridgend, Wales, said her son Louis ended up with teeth in his nose after a frightful accident at a water park while on holiday in TurkeyLouis was left seriously injured in the shocking accident while on holiday Image: Kelly GrfithsByAlice Suffield:,  Jan | commentsA -year-old boy was left with horrying injuries in a devastating accident on a hotel water slide. Stunned mum Kelly Grfiths said her son Louis ended up with teeth in his nose after the water at the pool was turned off. Grim photos show the treatment the schoolboy had to go through to get his smile back. Kelly told Wales Online there was blood everywhere and Louis had to be rushed to hospital. She said: I was actually back in the room, it was about .pm and Iaposd headed back up so I could shower before tea and thataposs when the kids my son had been at the pool with had come up to the room and said aposLouisapos knocked his front teeth outapos. Louis and some other kids had been climbing up the waterslide after the water had been turned off.His friend had made it up and had reached out his hand to pull Louis but he couldnapost grab it and fell flat on his face. His cousin Mason had carried him to the showers and there was blood everywhere.When I got down there they were already rushing him through into the doctoraposs room at the hotel and  mins later we were on our way to hospital.Louis, from Bridgend, was on a week-long family holiday in Antalya, Turkey, with his mum, nan, and his cousin, when he suffered the serious injuries. Kelly continues the story: We eventually were sent to the emergency dentist where he was seen by an oral surgeon. His teeth had been pushed all the way up into his nasal cavity, so it looked like he had a broken nose. Thanks to her former job, Kelly was well aware of what was at risk.  She said: Having been a dental nurse, I knew exactly how bad this could be, and it only made me worry more. These were his adult teeth so I knew he was at risk of losing them. Louis was operated on there at the dental surgery and had his teeth repositioned and splinted, all whilst he was awake. Kelly said: They gave him five injections of local anaesthetic and they cut his gum open and pulled the teeth back down and had them positioned by the splint. I think he was just in shock, in this country he would have been put to sleep. The holiday was ruined after that, and we were only on day two. We just wanted to come home.Louis couldnapost do anything, he couldnapost eat or drink properly and he couldnapost go in the pool. When the family ed to Wales, Louisaposs dentist had him referred to see specialists at Morriston Hospital, where the journey began to get his smile back. After ious treatment options had been exhausted, he was referred to Dr Rohini Mohan, Swansea Bay’s clinical lead for Community Dental Services, who successfully treated Louis at the Neath Port Talbot Resource Centre following the August  incident – and gave him back a perfect smile. Dr Mohan said: “The pictures of Louis have been inspirational to show other children who have suffered a trauma that you can come through it.It helps their parents as well. The worst can happen, and you can still come out with a beautul smile. Kelly said she couldnapost thank the dental team enough for helping Louis get his smile back. She said: Dr Rohini and her team were absolutely amazing. I canapost thank them enough for everything theyaposve done for Louis. title: britain should not involved tensions
story: Britain should not get involved in the tensions between Russia and UkrainePaul Routledge says we must not get dragged into the impending conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Armed Forces minister James Heappey warned tens of thousands could diewar breaks outVladimir Putin seems intent of rebuilding an influential Russian empire Image: SPUTNIK AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByPaul Routledge:,  Jan | comments All-out war between Russia and Ukraine appears imminent, and British brass hats can’t wait to join in.Armed Forces minister James Heappey talks blithely of the “grave possibility” of war with “tens of thousands dying.” Britain this week deployed an undisclosed number of Army personnel to the front line, a no manaposs land of freezing First World War-style trenches. They’re equipped with latest anti-tank weapons for use against the Red Army. They’re there to train Ukrainian soldiers, says the MoD, not to fight. But this is how wars begin. It’s called mission creep. The Americans were only in Vietnam to train local forces, until they weren’t. And look what happened.  If British soldiers come under direct fire, they must defend themselves. Then what  RAF sorties to take out attacking Russian forces  More, and bigger, military involvement  Tory MPs led by ex-officer Tobias Ellwood have formed a Charge of the Fight Brigade, egging on the military. How long before Boris Johnson begins to parade as the true successor to liberator Thatcher  But Donetsk isn’t British. This isn’t the Falklands. I’m no pacist –we’re invaded, stick a rle in my hands – and I hold no brief for dictator Vladimir Putin. His ambition to rebuild a Russian empire of influence from the ruins of the USSR is clear. But this is not our fight. They are not at the gates of Greenwich, and Nato is a reliable bulwark against any such danger. The Germans, who have much more to lose from a conflict close to their borders, promise “everything short of war”: punitive sanctions to hit the Russian economy hard. We should do the same. The coal mines of the Donbas are not worth the le of a single British soldier. title: christian couple ban gay men
story: Christian couple ban gay men from buying home - and refuse to let them insideLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell wanted to buy a house but the sellers told them they would not be allowed to even view it as they believe homosexuality is contrary to Gods wordLuke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell fell in love with the £,, three-bed Image: Triangle NewsByAndy CrickTom ParrySpecial correspondentDanya Bazaraa:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A gay couple who inquired about a house they wanted to buy were banned by the owners from even viewing it as they said homosexuality is “contrary to the word of God”.Luke Whitehouse and Lachlan Mantell were sent a message from the sellers, who are Christians, citing Bible passages that are used to condemn same-sex relationships.Luke and Lachlan, who have been together for eight years, planned to view the house in Coulsdon, Surrey last Saturday.But on the Wednesday before they got a message back from the sellers via Purplebricks.It read: Dear Lachlan and Luke, thank you for sharing your circumstances with us.Weaposre sorrywe seem intrusive, but we just want to make clear that we would be unwilling for two men in a partnership to view or buy our house. Have you had a similar experience  Email webnews@mirrorAs it is contrary to the gracious teaching in Godaposs Word, the Holy Bible, e.g Romans :- and Jude  . With regards.Speaking about his reaction, Luke said: “For the first  seconds I laughed – I thought it was a joke. But then I was upset and I had a cry on the phone to my mum. Homophobia still exists.”Business owner Luke, , and ITV producer Lachlan, , said it was their first attempt to view a house as they look to get on the property ladder. Luke and Lachlan - originally from Adelaide, Australia - are desperate to get their own place after being kept apart during the pandemic, He said: We were separated during Covid, he was in America while I was here, we were forced apart. Buying a house was something that we wanted to do for a long time. But this was the only house we planned for a viewing. We were looking forward to going this weekend.  He added: Since I came out eight years ago I have not come across discirimation. I probably have been discriminated against but was just not aware of it. Luke, of Putney, south west London said they wouldnapost buy or even view the house eventhe owners apologised and changed their mind. He added: We will look for something  now We are not going to let it affect us trying to buy a house.  Married couple Luke Main, , a builder, and medical physicist Dr Joanna Brunker, , own the £,, three-bed home in Coulsdon, South London. Dr Brunker reportedly hit back at the criticism by saying: “We’re practising Christians and are sticking to our beliefs and haven’t done anything wrong.”Luke reported it to the online estate agents who were selling it via Rightmove.They are set to stop selling the property saying the comments from the owners are against its views and values.A Purplebricks spokesperson told them: Thanks for sharing this message Lachlan and weaposre so sorry youaposve had this experience.This stance is completely opposed to our views and values.Weaposll refund this selleraposs fee as Purplebricks no longer wish to list it. A Purplebricks spokesperson added: The sentiments expressed in this message are completely opposed to Purplebricksapos views and values.We have contacted the seller totheir fee and request that they sell their property with a dferent agent.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CrimeGayDaily MirrorHousing,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: coat banning school blames upsetting
story: Coat-banning school blames upsetting and abusive parents over strict new policyBishop Heber school in Malpas, Cheshire, believeschildren were allowed to wear their own coats it would "erode the great relationships" they have with their studentsParents are furious after a new strict branded unorm policy meant children were stopped from wearing their own coats outside Image: MEN MEDIABySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan | comments A school that stopped children wearing coats without its logo on have hit out at angry parents who called-out their strict policy.Pupils at Bishop Heber in Malpas, Cheshire, can only wear a costly branded jacket on school grounds, it has been decided.Mums and dads slammed the new unorm approach, which means their kids are prevented from wearing their own coats outside during breaks and to get to and from school, reports CheshireLive. Some even had their jackets confiscated as temperatures plunged during a chilly start to . Now Bishop Heber have hit out at the parents for abusive language while branding their fury upsetting. What do you think about this story  Let us know in the comments below  One mum said her asthmatic son was put into isolation for retrieving his seized coat because he was so cold. Photos taken by irate parents show staff milling around outside in warm overcoats while some children are just in thin jumpers with temperatures as low as C. Last week, the school said it believeskids were allowed to wear their own coats it would erode the great relationships we have with the students after fears they might end up wearing hoodies. After more backlash, they have now urged parents to raise concerns in a more formal manner.  A statement from the school read: Almost  years ago, the school made a commitment to an affordable unorm policy, and we believe the current unorm is one of the cheapest to buy in the region and complies with the affordable school unorm legislation being introduced this year. The coat was chosen and designed by students in  and costs £. The school is confident that students are not sitting in classrooms that are unusually cold for the time of year and students should not need to wear coats to keep warm. Additionally, all students have access to an indoor space and or classroom during any breaks.  We hope that parents and the wider community appreciate that governors and school leaders are trying to do their best in what has been an exceptionally dficult period for us all. Governors hope that parents will use the school complaints policythey have a concern. Such complaints can be dealt with formally and carefully and without some of the upsetting, abusive and inflammatory language that has been directed at staff and governors. Parents complained about the cost and quality of the branded windcheater which costs £. One angry mum fumed: “They confiscated his my sonaposs coat yesterday - outside - which I thought was absolutely ludicrous. He has asthma, which he is on constant medication for, so getting cold does him no good whatsoever. Because he went and got his coat back because he was cold, he has been put into isolation, that was his punishment. “Why would you take a coat off a child when you know they’ve got asthma  She added: “Kids should not be worried about getting into trouble for keeping warm. title: dad named one sickest covid
story: Dad named one of sickest Covid patients comes off oxygen a year after getting virusAndrew Watts, , of Bexley, south London, spent a total of  hours in hospital and had to relearn how to walk and talk following eight months in intensive careAndrew Watts, , was finally able tohome after  days in hospital Image: BPM MEDIAByLucy WilliamsonLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA dad described one of the sickest ever Covid patients has just started breathing without oxygen support more than a year after catching the virus. Andrew Watts, , had one of the longest hospital stays doctors had ever seen after spending eight months in intensive care followed by another two months on a ward.The dad-of-two spent  days at Queen Elizabeth Hospital where he was admitted with Covid- pneumonia on Christmas Day in .In February, after a five-week induced coma and two le-threatening lung collapses, doctors called Mr Wattsapos we Hayley to discuss switching off his ventilator because his condition had deteriorated so badly.But the family insisted he should be given more time and he has since left hospital - and now he has come off a nasal cannula for the first time, reports My London.Mr Watts, from Bexley in South London, was finally able to go home in October and said he is doing well but still battles with ongoing complications.  The cab driver, who was in remission from lymph cancer at the time, had to relearn how to walk and talk after spending so long on a ventilator. In intensive care, he used a tracheostomy pipe and had to communicate with his we using letters on a board. Only a week and a half ago, I came off a nasal cannula for the first time since leaving hospital, Mr Watts said. I used it for nine hours every night to aid my recovery to help my lungs get back to some sort of normality. The cabbie told how he has not healed properly after the ventilator and tube was in his neck for so long in hospital. Thataposs why there is a whistle when Iaposm talking as there is essentially a hole in my neck where air comes out, he added.  I canapost get water in it or it makes me cough like mad. I could get an infection which means I canapost go swimming and I canapost shower the way I want to. Mr Wattsapos family, including Hayley and sons Jack, six, and Joshua, three, have all supported his recovery. In November, Mr Watts said his major goal was to walk his sons to school and he can currently walk for up to  minutes walking before his legs start burning. I managed to get to my son’s school and back last Monday. I say that - we parked around the corner, so it wasnapost the full way. But still, he said. I think people should be grateful that they can do these little tasks. Day-to-day, when youaposre fit and healthy, you just do these things and donapost think about.  But when it got taken away from me, it made me realise not to take it for granted. When Mr Watts first went into hospital in December , he had not been vaccinated, due to the very early stage of the vaccination campaign - but he has since had three doses of a Covid vaccine. Looking back on his experience, which included doctors at one time calling his family to tell them they were considering turning his ventilator off, Mr Watts urged others to get vaccinated. When in hospital, he recalled how they did not believe that vaccinations would do anything and that the whole pandemic was a conspiracy. “The fact that there are people that know what Iaposve been through and still say that, he said. Itaposs up to iniduals. If it was me, I would tell them to go and get it. If they decide not to get it, then that’s their own fault. Andrew said he was badly impacted by the virus because he was in remission from lymph cancer after successful chemotherapy treatment. It comes as the Prime Minister today announced the end of Plan B measures - with the onus now falling on the British public to mitigate the risks of Covid. Mr Watts welcomes the change, despite still being clinically vulnerable. He said I want everyone to live their lives to the max, this isnapost going anywhere we’ve got to learn to live with it. “I could wrap myself in cotton wool and live in a box but then whataposs the point in living  I want the world to get back” “Itaposs unlikely I would get it again. Iaposm taking necessary precautions, I have kids that go to school, but what can you do  I wear a mask where I have to and continue to wash my hands because otherwise whataposs the point  Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Oxygen OneCoronavirus vaccineCoronavirusHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family welcomes first girl born
story: Family welcomes first girl born in  years with touching photo of  generationsGreat-grandmother Gwen Smith, , from Northfleet, Kent, welcomed baby Maeva - the first girl born into her family since her own daughter in Gwen Smith meets her great great granddaughter MaevaByAdam Gillham:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A -year-old pensioner has greeted her great-great-granddaughter into the world - the first girl born into the family for  years.Gwen Smith met little Maeva for the first time - the first female born to the Smiths since her daughter Sandra in .Five generations of the family were able to get together at the Dene Holm Residential Care Home in Northfleet, Kent, as the oldest and youngest members could be united for the first time.Gwen, who will turn  next month, already has five grandsons, eight great-grandsons and six step-great-grandsons - and she was extremely proud to meet the newest addition to the family. Unfortunately, her cataracts mean she can no longer see very well, but she was still tremendously happy to meet Maeva. Gwen’s family said: “It was a very special occasion to get all five generations together, particularly during the pandemic. Strict protocols are still in place but the home’s manager, Chris, permitted the visit for which we are all extremely grateful.” Gwen was born in Essex on February , , and moved to Gravesend as a youngster, attending school in Northfleet. She was a keen dancer in her youth and performed at many local events while working for her father’s shop.  Gwen met her husband, Ron, an apprentice electrician at Blue Circle Cement Works, when she was . They married in , but with Ron sent to serve overseas in the Royal Engineers they didn’t meet again for another five years. When they were finally reunited the pair enjoyed many years of travelling whilst bringing up their two daughters, Gloria and Sandra. A care home spokesman said: It can be dficult to get several generations of family together at the best of times but with an ongoing pandemic, it’s even trickier. But thanks to the staff at the Dene Holm Road care home, Gwen’s family were able to come and visit her together, to introduce her to baby Maeva. It was a very rare occasion and indeed, incredibly special for the whole family, particularly as little Maeva is the first girl to be born to the family since Gwen’s daughter, Sandra,  years ago. title: happy cheeky funny boy 13
story: Happy, cheeky, funny boy, , dies after being hit by train at railway stationDevin Gordon, , was reportedly hit by a train near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday, according to British Transport PoliceDevin Gordon was reportedly hit by a train Image: Bathgate Juniors Football ClubByDan BarkerRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The family of a teenager who died after reportedly being hit by a train have said their lives will never be the same without our precious boy. Devin Gordon, , died near Bathgate railway station in West Lothian, Scotland, on Wednesday afternoon, British Transport Policesaid.In a tribute to the keen footballer, his family said he will live in our hearts forever. In their statement, issued by the police, they continued: Our lives have changed forever and will never be the same without our precious boy. We will miss him every day for the rest of our lives. Thank-you to everyone thataposs paid tribute to Devin and those that have sent us condolence messages during this extremely dficult time.Have you been affected by this incident  Let us know at webnews@mirrorHearts fan Devin was a member of Bathgate Juniors Football Club, which described him as a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. It said: Devin was a light in the team which will never go out. His personality like a magnet drawing people to him. Happy, cheeky but funny with it and always respectful. On the field he showed his passion and skill. He made the team a better place to be. He was a great team player and friend who will be greatly missed by his football family. Our thoughts are now with Devinaposs family, friends and his team who will hold him in their hearts foreverthe only number .  Emergency services had attended the scene, but could not save the youngster. Police said his death is not been treated as suspicious and a report will be sent to the procurator fiscal. Emergency services raced to the scene at around .pm yesterday but sadly the teen could not be saved and was pronounced dead. A BTP statement said: British Transport Police were called to Bathgate station at .pm todayfollowing reports of a casualty on the tracks. Paramedics also attended, and sadly a person was pronounced dead at the scene. The incident is not being treated as suspicious and a file will be prepared for the procurator fiscal. Devinaposs friends are hoping to get a -minute applause around Heartsapos Tynecastle Park when the side face Celtic next Wednesday. news uk-news kate-middleton-jokes-dog-upset-"Kate Middleton and Prince William cuddle pup on visit to LancashireByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge couldnapost hide her delight after she got to cuddle up to a cute puppy on a visit to a hospital today - and joked her own dog would be upset. Kate and husband Prince William were at Clitheroe Community Hospital in Lancashire this afternoon meeting staff to learn what it has been like for them during the coronavirus pandemic.For the visit, Kate wore a recycled £ Massimo Dutti that sheaposs been spotted wearing at two other engagements. She teamed the coat with a gorgeous camel polo neck jumper and matching skirt and completed the look with tan boots. During the visit to the hospital, Kate and William got to meet  week-old cockapoo Alfie.The pup, who licked Williamaposs cheek, will be trained to support patients and colleagues at the East Lancashire HospitalsNHS Trust alongside therapy dog Jasper.Kate described the pup as so sweet but, after enjoying a cuddle, added: Our dog is going to be very upset.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. The couple also met GPs, nurses, and patients at the hospital. William told staff: Weaposre so grateful for all your hard work. Iaposm not sure there are enough words to say how grateful everyone is for what you have done. He said he had a particular affinity with staff because of his time as an air ambulance pilot. Lisa Kay, intensive home support service clinical lead, said: That was great to hear because itaposs not every day you get a royal visit to say thank you.  It has been a huge morale boost. Patient Bill Taylor, , was asked by the royals about the care he had received at the hospital and joked: Theyaposre trying their best but thereaposs some awkward b*****s. The retired policeman praised the hospital food, telling the couple he had a grand meat and potato pie for his lunch. He said: We all enjoy ourselves up here. But weaposd like you to come up more often.  He pointed out Pendle Hill, seen from the window of his ward, and told them: The kids would enjoy it.The Duke and Duchess, who are joint royal patrons of NHS Charities Together, heard how support from hospital charity ELHTMe had helped staff at the trust, which is in one of the areas of the country worst affected by Covid-.A grant of more than £, from NHS Charities Together, following the public response to its Covid- Urgent Appeal, allowed the charity to fund equipment and infrastructure for the staff wellbeing team, as well as the new therapy dog. Director of operations Catriona Logan said the duchess was really interested to know how the pandemic had been for staff. She said: We talked about how dficult it was for patients and families being separated by visiting restrictions. She was really engaging. Professor Eileen Fairhurst, trust chairwoman, added: It was really uplting for our staff a real morale boost that their work has been recognised by this high profile visit, and itaposs testament to the hard work and commitment of all our colleagues in the trust in the real challenges and dficulties we have faced since the pandemic. We have been hardest hit in this part of the country and it has really not gone away. title: man slept ae chair 4
story: Man slept on AE chair for  nights after arriving with spreading skin complaintJohn Evans, , arrived at Cardfs University Hospital, Wales, with a skin infection which was rapidly spreading across his face - but was left shocked at the conditions staff were working inDespite the inadequate conditions, John praised the staff for trying their best and being so caring Image: InternetByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A man spent four nights sleeping on an AE chair after arriving with a fast-spreading skin condition.John Evans arrived at Cardfaposs University Hospital in Wales with a skin infection spreading across his face. The -year-old said he had experienced the skin problem before, so knew he needed urgent treatment and antibiotics.But as he waited for a hospital bed to become free, John said he was left on a chair for four nights - despite staff doing their best in tough working conditions.Speaking about his hospital ordeal, John said: I was really shocked by the conditions that the patients and staff were in. There was only one toilet to use and no hot food. Despite the inadequate conditions, John praised the staff for trying their best and being so caring, reports the BBC.He said: The staff did a fantastic job and they worked really hard and theyaposre so caring, but they were under real pressure as well. There was a sense of helplessness from the staff to the point where they had to just manage their way through a horric situation, caring for people in this way. Iaposd always believed that the health service was thereI needed it. Cardf and Vale health board said it was in touch with Mr Evans and sincerely apologised.  In a statement, the board said: Our services are under extreme pressure due to a number of factors including current staff shortages and the sustained challenges coronavirus presents.In addition, health and social care services across Cardf and the Vale of Glamorgan are experiencing signicant and sustained pressures which is impacting the timely discharge of patients from hospital. These and other challenges are impacting on patient flow within our sites and, in turn, waiting times in our emergency unit. In this instance, we sincerely apologise for the delays and experience for Mr Evans, and our concerns team are in touch with him to respond directly to the concerns raised.There are currently , beds in Welsh hospitals occupied by medically fit people who cannot secure care and thus cannot be released from AE.As a result, more than , patients waited more than  hours to be admitted to AE in Wales during November. news uk-news meghan-markle-prince-harry-might-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Prince Harry and Meghan Markle could miss Prince Philip’s upcoming memorialtheir security fight is not resolved.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expected to attend the service in spring this year and finally introduce seven-month old Lilibet to the Queen and other members of the royal family.But the plans are on hold due to Harryaposs legal dispute with the UK Government over a decision not to let him pay for police protection for his family when he is visiting.A legal representative of the prince said he wants to bring Lilibet and two-year-old son Archie to visit from the US but they are “unable toto his home” because it is too dangerous. Last July, Harry was reportedly chased by a pack of photographers after he attended a charity event with sick children at Kew Gardens, west London.Whose side are you on  Have your say in the comment section The -year-old had flown back briefly from LA for the July  unveiling of the Diana, Princess of Wales memorial statue. The Sussexes have their own security in the US, but sources said the privately paid-for team have no authority whatsoever in the UK.And one royal source has now told Page Six : “If Harry goes, he will want to have security for him and his family. If and when he decides to go back to the UK, he needs security.” The couple have not announced any official travel plans for  as yet but it has been widely believed they would attend the service in memory of the Duke of Edinburgh who died last April at the age of . This would be the first time Lilbet would meet her paternal side of her family as Meghan has not ed to the UK since the couple officially quit royal le in March  and lost their taxpayer-funded police protection. The Mirror has contacted the Sussexes for a comment.  On Saturday, Harryaposs legal representatives said that he has filed a claim for judicial review because he wants to fund the security himself, rather than ask taxpayers to foot the bill. He has argued that his private protection team in the US does not have the necessary jurisdiction abroad, or access to UK intelligence that is needed to keep his family safe.In a statement to PA news agency, the legal representative for the Duke said: “The UK will always be Prince Harry ’s home and a country he wants his we and children to be safe in. “With the lack of police protection, comes too great a personal risk. “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex personally fund a private security team for their family, yet that security cannot replicate the necessary police protection needed whilst in the UK. “In the absence of such protection, Prince Harry and his family are unable toto his home.” The legal representative added: “Prince Harry inherited a security risk at birth, for le. He remains sixth in line to the throne, served two tours of combat duty in Afghanistan, and in recent years his family has been subjected to well-documented neo-Nazi and extremist threats.  “While his role within the Institution has changed, his profile as a member of the Royal Family has not. Nor has the threat to him and his family.” The bid for a judicial review was filed in September. Dai Davies, former head of Scotland Yard’s royal protection unit, told the Mirror: If ever there was a proper credible threat to Prince Harry or his family then the Met would take the appropriate action. “If he or his family were toto Britain in an official capacity or to support the Queen during the Platinum Jubilee events I’m sure he would be afforded the necessary protection. “I would argue robustly against his case that he is not safe in the UK. If ever the British intelligence services did discover a threat to him and his family they are hardly going to sit on it. It appears that Harry is creating scenarios that do not exist.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Meghan MarklePrince HarryPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum 63 sheds 5st chucks
story: Mum, , sheds st and chucks old swimsuit away after family creates own fat loss dietEmma Scrivener, , from Swansea, Wales, and her family shed an impressive st in just months after inventing their own clean living dietEmma Scrivener, husband Tony, their daughter Katie Thomas and husband Shaun invented the diet Image: DA GroupByAndrea Blazquez:,  Jan | comments A family lost a combined  stone between them after coming up with their own diet.Emma Scrivener, , her husband Tony, their daughter mum-of-three Katie Thomas and husband Shaun created a plan that they say is easy to stick to. Emma, from Swansea, Wales, explained she was a size  when she decided to lose weight following a health scare.My blood pressure was extremely high and I had problems with my back and realised that something had to be done before I got progressively worse, she told the . Also we had been on a holiday and after seeing myself in a swimsuit realised I had piled on the weight.Have you been through a weight loss journey like Emma and her family  Let us know at webnews@mirror I had to make the decision that I would do nothing and regret it later or make the changes before it became too late. She went on to say she never expected to drop down to a size , but knewshe could get to a size  she would be very happy. What has become known as the DA diet consists of most foods, including treats like chocolate, crisps and cake.  But is about portion control. Emma said many people may be eating well but eating far too much. Her plan is well balanced with the correct amounts of protein, fats and carbohydrates.  It took her around  months to reach her target weight, losing five stone, as she was going through menopause. Shaun, on the other hand, lost five stone in five months, while Katie lost two stone in three months and Tony three and a half in five months. Emma said it should never be a race to lose weight and it is about each inidualaposs well-being. She admits her le has drastically changed after sticking it out, with no blood pressure issues or aches and pains. Emma was able to throw her old swimsuits away and now has no body confidence issues.The family started their weight loss journey in  and have since set up the DA Group which provides plans, as well as natural supplements, and includes Facebook groups and mentoring.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON DA GroupBlood pressureDietMenopauseSwimming costumesWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum who sent 6000 run
story: Mum who sent £, to on-the-run drug dealer boyfriend in Dubai spared jailAnnie Webster, , from Liverpool, wired £,. to her then-boyfriend and renowned drug dealer Shawn OMalley, who was on the run from police in Dubai in relation to a gangland shootingAnnie Webster, , of Cumberland Street, Warrington, appeared back in Liverpool Crown Court on Thursday Image: Liverpool EchoByCharlotte Hadfield:,  Jan | commentsA mum who sent more than £, to her drug dealing boyfriend who was on the run over a shooting in Dubai was today spared jail. Annie Webster, , wired £,. to her then-partner Shawn OaposMalley, who was on the run from police following the shooting in Bolton. OaposMalley, from Warrington, was wanted by police in relation to a shooting in Bolton on September , , when a house was sprayed with bullets. He was jailed for  years at Liverpool Crown Court in September, after being convicted for the attack which he organised on behalf of Warrington criminal Leon Cullen.His prison sentence also related to the torture of two men at a remote cannabis farm, where he tied, beat and threatenedthem with weapons including a pickaxe and sledgehammer, the Liverpool Echo reports. In July, Bolton Crown Court heard how OaposMalleyaposs partner Webster sent thousands of pounds to him while he was on the run in Dubai in relation to a gangland shooting. When police visited Websteraposs home in January  she told them she had split from OaposMalley in November  and was no longer in contact with him. On March , , police executed a warrant at Websteraposs home in Warrington, when she was arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. During a search of her house police recovered a number of items including a Western Union Money Transfer Document in her name, an Emirates Economy Boarding Pass in her name and a receipt voucher for a Dubai-based law firm. From a storage area under the stairs in her home, police found a money transfer receipt for £. dated February , , a Ghaya Brand Hotel luggage claim ticket, a money transfer receipt dated February , , and her passport. Following a police search and interview, Webster pleaded guilty to concealing, disguising, converting, transferring or removing criminal property. A charge of conspiring to pervert the course of justice will also lay on file. Webster, of Cumberland Street, Warrington, was sentenced to a two-year community order with a -day rehabilitation activity requirement at Bolton Crown Court back in July last year.  But she appeared back in Liverpool Crown Court today where she admitted breaching the terms of her community order. Rebecca Smith, prosecuting, told the court Webster has so far completed five days of the rehabilitation activity requirement since the community order was imposed last summer. However, the -year-old failed to attend two planned appointments with probation in September and November . Websteraposs defence barrister, Kate Morley, told the court her client suffers with anxiety and depression and finds it easier to engage on the telephone as opposed to leaving her home to attend office appointments at times. Ms Morley said Webster had missed the appointments in September and November due to childcare issues with her six-year-old son, who was unwell and has had to have six teeth removed.The court heard Webster also had to self-isolate after her mum tested positive for Covid- until she received a negative test result.Ms Morley said while her client should have picked up the phone and informed probation of this she didnapost and she apologises for that.  The court heard Webster is now working in a local bar and hasnapost committed any other offences. Ms Morley said: She has attended today despite her father sadly suffering a heart attack and passing away last week. Sentencing, Judge Robert Trevor-Jones said: Iaposm quite sure that when you were sentenced to this community order back in June last year you would have been told what would happenyou failed to comply with it, so here you are now because of that. The judge said that while he had the power to revoke Websteraposs community order and resentence her to imprisonment, he was not going to do that on the grounds that this is her first conviction and first breach, and because she has a six-year-old son. However, he warned thatWebster continues not to meet the requirements of the community order she will be brought back to court to face the consequences. Webster was handed a fine of £ which must be paid over the next six months. title: nursery accidentally sends parents secret
story: Nursery accidentally sends parents secret letter of string of worrying mistakesOne incident claimed that a child became trapped in the toilet crying and shaking while another almost escaped from the nursery in Enderby, LeicestershireStaff at Welcome Nurseries, which owns Smarties, in Enderby, mistakenly posted the message Image: Andy Baker Leicestershire LiveByCorey BedfordLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Nursery staff accidentally posted a secret letter to parents revealing a string of mistakes including a boy getting stuck in the loo and a near escape.Staff at Welcome Nurseries, which owns Smarties, posted a message by mistake on the Family nursery app which is used to communicate with mums and dads. Another incident claimed a toddler was left to sit with dried faeces on his leg and another child was trapped in the toilet crying and shaking, according to the file. The horrying message said they wouldnapost be surprisedOfsted donapost turn up by the end of the week at the centre in Enderby, Leicestershire.But it was quickly taken down and was replaced with a notice attempting to reassure parents it had been posted in error by a member of staff at the firmaposs head office, reports Leicestershire Live.The biggest issue to emerge from the post referred to an incident last July when a child almost wandered out of the nursery and into the car park via a gate that had supposedly been left open by a staff member. It told how the staff member reported the incident to the then-manager and deputy manager. However the incident was not reported to the totaposs family, the head office or Ofsted, the company told the publication.  The company said the head office was only made aware of the incident in early January and that it had contacted the childaposs parents to inform them of what had happened. It added that an investigation into several incidents is currently underway with a new management team now running the nursery. Staff also acknowledged that workers did not whistle-blow to superiors after realising the management had not reported the incident however employees have since retrained to report such issues in future. The letter also detailed how a pre-school boy was trapped in the toilet for some time, leaving them visibly shaking and crying when let out. It claimed that the incident happened when a staff member was told to close the door to the bathroom to stop children running in and out and did not check the cubicles to seeany children were still left inside. Welcome Nurseries said the door was accidentally closed while the child was inside but staff then realised and ed to let him out. Other issues reported in the accidental post included a staff member wiping babiesapos bottoms with antibacterial wipes instead of wet wipes, causing the babies to have sore and bleeding bottoms. Meanwhile a cook was left to supervise pre-school children alone with no qualications to do so, it claimed. A child in soiled nappy was left unattended for so long that faeces was stuck to his leg and took  minutes to remove. One parent, whose child attends the nursery, said: The entire post is very worrying but my child attends the nursery section so I am particularly concerned that a member of staff was using antibacterial wipes on the babiesapos bottoms. I definitely havenapost been told about it and only found out due to the letter. We have to provide our own baby wipes so there was literally no excuse for them to use anything , they are completely dferent. They have covered staff mistakes up and we wouldnapost have known about itthe letter wasnapost posted. The nursery was already unreliable generally before this and had caused some concern, but hearing about a child escaping in the summer makes me worry , as a parent, will I find outmy child has been put at risk  Itaposs just a lot to hide. If theyaposd spoken with parents immediately at the time, there would have been some angry people, sure, but itaposs a lot better than keeping it a secret. The parent is looking to move their child to an alternative nursery in the near future. They added: The trust is gone with them. Iaposm having to move them to another nursery, which is a big disruption for a developing child, but itaposs something Iaposm having to do to ensure they are safe. Welcome Nurseries confirmed the management in charge of Smarties Nursery has changed since the incidents in question, and that the company was tackling the situation as a matter or urgency. The spokesperson said: We can confirm that we received an email of concern on the th January regarding alleged incidents that took place around July last year, under previous management. We can also confirm that we had no prior knowledge of the incidents until the email was sent to us. The safety and well-being of all our children are our number one priority and we immediately carried out a full investigation. It was alleged that a child managed to escape from the nursery into the car park. Whilst this allegation was unfounded, on investigation it was found that a gate was left open which was seen on CCTV by the receptionist, who acted immediately before the child went out of the gate. We also investigated further incidents which occurred around the same time in which a child was left in the bathroom on their own. Our investigation found that a child had entered the bathroom area and a member of staff not knowing he was there closed the door. Both incidents were reported to the previous management team who are no longer with the company, however these were not reported onward or investigated at the time. These incidents fall well below our standard of care and we have since retrained our staff. We are continuing to work with our parents and can assure all parents that we take all concerns seriously and act on them. We profusely apologise to all our children and parents that these incidents occurred and that we were not made aware of them sooner. We have not yet finished our investigations in this matter. We have a new management structure in place at the setting. We would also like to thank our parents for their continued support. A Leicestershire County Council spokesperson said: “We have very recently been made aware of concerns raised by a parent and will be working with the setting to ensure the appropriate procedures and policies are in place. news uk-news prince-andrew-demanded-room-temperature-"Prince Andrew: Former royal bodyguard discusses teddiesBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew demanded his water be strictly served at room temperature and that his valet haul around a six-foot ironing board on foreign trips, it has been claimed. Sources say the Duke was known for being rude and having childish obsessions - as he was ridiculed while on the road fulfilling royal duties, reports claim.It comes after reports the embattled Duke of York would allegedly scream and shoutBuckingham Palace servants failed to follow his exact plan for the arrangement of his teddy bears. Now more supposed demanding behaviour has come to light during his term as the UKaposs special representative for trade and investment. It includes suggestions he was privately mocked in the Gulf during his time as a special envoy.  A diplomat says the Prince became known as HBH - His Buffoon Highness. The former deputy head of mission in Bahrain, Simon Wilson, says the royalaposs travelling entourage left people speechless. He told The Times Andrew flew out a team which included his equerries and private secretaries. His valet would be equipped with a huge ironing board to ensure his clothes were perfectly pressed, it was claimed.  The diplomat, who had previously hosted the Duke, added that Andrew was rude and boorish and wasnapost well-liked. Mr Wilson explained he was known as a buffoon because of his childish obsession with doing the exact opposite of what had been agreed. He immediately warned that Andrewaposs private le would “willy-nilly, intrude into his public role” – and that he could be “going off with Ghislaine Maxwell to a nightclub” during his private time, it was claimed.Andrew has effectively been banished from the royal family less than  hours after learning a civil sex case against him in New York will go ahead.  The latest awkward anecdotes come after Tuesdayaposs claims that Andrew sketched out a plan for how his five teddies and cuddly toys should be positioned on his bed every night. Ex protection officer Paul Page tells ITV ’s Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile that would “scream and shout”his servants failed to place them exactly how he wanted. He supplied a handwritten guide is said to have included two hippos, a black panther and bears, as well as three cushions called aposDaddyapos, aposDucksapos and aposPrinceapos. It showed exactly where to place blankets, as well as five toys and a fur, which had ribbons that had to hang off the side of the bed, it is said. Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile host Ranvir Singh unravels the story of how Maxwell sank into shame and disgrace through her friendship with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. And will also explore how Andrew became embroiled in the scandal as he faces his own possible civil court case brought by Virginia Giuffre. Andrew has strenuously denied the allegations made by Ms Giuffre against him. title: prince andrew loses another honour
story: Prince Andrew loses another honour as school changes name to distance itself from DukeHead of Prince Andrew High School, Craig Campbell, in Nova Scotia sent an email to families explaining the name change - branding the decision "exciting news" after years of concerns from parents and committee membersThe schools concerns began in , when Andrew was accused of having sex with an underage girl trafficked by paedophile friend Jeffrey Epstein Image: Getty ImagesByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew has lost another honour after a school changed its name to distance itself from the Duke and his ongoing civil sex case. Head of Prince Andrew High School, Craig Campbell, in Nova Scotia sent an email to families explaining the name change - branding the decision exciting news. The email explained: The name of a school should be reflective of our school community and uphold our values as a safe and inclusive learning space for all. “Our hope is to continue to build our identity as a positive, supportive and respectful community, with a name to match.” The school was named in honour of the Queenaposs son in  after he was born. However, the name has been a point of concern since  - when Andrew was accused of having sex with an underage girl trafficked by paedophile friend Jeffrey Epstein.  Officials in the school originally formed committees in  to discuss a name change after the Duke of York was taken off royal duties as allegations against him began to circulate, despite his denials of any wrongdoing, reports New York Post. One mother of pupils at the school and chair of the school advisory council, Belinda Oxner, said in : As mother-of-three daughters, I find it very dficult to have that name on a building with the allegations and the associations now with the Prince Andrew name. The school will choose a new name in time ready for the new school year in September, the principal said. Mr Campbell added: We’re ready and excited to take this next step. It comes after the Queen stripped Andrew of his royal titles and patronages, meaning he will fight his accuser’s Manhattan lawsuit as a “private citizen.” A Buckingham Palace spokesperson said: With The Queen’s approval and agreement, The Duke of York’s military affiliations and Royal patronages have been ed to The Queen. The Duke of York will continue not to undertake any public duties and is defending this case as a private citizen. A royal source said: All of The Duke’s roles have been handed back to The Queen with immediate effect for redistribution to other Members of the Royal Family - will notto The Duke of York. The Duke of York will no longer use the style ‘His Royal Highness’ in any official capacity. Prince Andrew served in the Royal Navy as a helicopter pilot and saw active service in the Falklands War. The royal said he stopped sweating after suffering an overdose of adrenaline while being shot at in the conflict.  The Duke revealed this medical condition in a BBC Newsnight interview when addressing Ms Giuffreaposs description of him sweating profusely. The royal has denied all allegations made against him, including claims he was sweating during a meeting with Ms Gufre. Prince Andrew has lost the following military affiliations:Honorary Air Commodore at RAF Lossiemouth Commodore-in-Chief of the Fleet Air Arm Colonel of the Grenadier Guards – Colonel Colonel in Chief of the Princess Louise Fusiliers of Canada Colonel in Chief of the Queenaposs York RangersColonel in Chief of the Royal Highland FusiliersColonel in Chief of the Royal Irish Regiment , rd and th and The Ulster Defence Regiment Colonel in Chief of the Royal New Zealand Army Logistic RegimentColonel in Chief of the Small Arms School Corps Colonel in Chief of the Royal LancersRoyal Colonel of the Royal Highland Fusiliers, nd Battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland Colonel in Chief of the Yorkshire Regiment Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON The QueenPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkBuckingham PalaceRoyal NavyFalklands WarNewsnightEducationRoyal FamilySchoolsArmed forcesSecondary schoolThe Falklands" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queen-never-meet-lilibet-amid-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments Thereaposs a big possibility the Queen may never get to meet her great-granddaughter Lilibet, according to a royal expert.Prince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs seven-month-old daughter was born in Calornia in June and her parents have yet to bring her to the UK.Since moving to the US, Meghan and two-year-old Archie have not ed at all, and Harry has only been back twice. And at the weekend, Harry revealed the reason why heaposs yet to bring his family to his homeland. He claims his private security arrangements are not enough to ensure his family’s safety and privacy here. He and Meghan are no longer entitled to police protection.  Harry now wants to pay for specialist police protection, but the Home Office has ruled this out – and he has applied for a judicial review against the decision. If the row canapost be solved, Harry might choose not to bring his young children to the UK.And with the Queen no longer flying long-haul, royal expert Phil Dampier told The Sun itaposs a big possibility she is never going to meet her granddaughter Lilibet and has only ever met Archie once or twice.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He also added: Getting his protection reinstated would set a precedent and so it gives them the perfect opportunity to say we can’t come to Platinum Jubilee celebrations. Harry might come over but it gives Meghan a good excuse not to come and also not to bring the children. Meanwhile, another royal expert previously claimed the Queen finds it dficult that she has been unable to see Harry and Meghan’s children.Speaking in the Channel  documentary : The Queen’s Terrible Year, royal expert Camilla Tominey says it has been hard for the Queen to be so far away from her two great-grandchildren. She said: Iaposm sure the Queen was absolutely delighted to hear the news that the Sussexes were expecting a second child. She continued: But it is dficult for the Queen. She has not been able to see Archie. I think the last time she was able to see Archie in the flesh was November . The only way the Queen will be able to see these children isthey come over to the UK. Maybe she will see them next year when she marks her Platinum Jubilee. We have to wait and see. title: senior royal spends birthday volunteering
story: Senior royal spends birthday volunteering at NHS vaccine centre in fight against CovidSophie, Countess of Wessex, spent her th birthday today volunteering at an NHS Covid vaccination centre in Surrey where shes previously done shts throughout the pandemicSophie, The Countess of Wessex, volunteered at a vaccination centre on her th birthday Image: PAByTony JonesRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan | comments The Countess of Wessex has spent her birthday volunteering with St John Ambulance at an NHS vaccination centre.Sophie, who turned  on Thursday, was pictured wearing a face mask while she worked at a centre in Surrey greeting patients, taking their details and looking after their wellbeing while they had their jabs.At the end of her morning sht, she was presented with a Covid pin badge to thank her for her support during the pandemic, as well as a bouquet of flowers to mark her birthday.Sophie, the SJAaposs grand president, trained as a care volunteer in support of the NHS vaccination programme and did a number of shts last year.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  Ann Cable, the SJAaposs chief commissioner, said: We are honoured that the Countess of Wessex chose to spend her birthday with St John. It is a testament to the outstanding contribution of our volunteers, not just in response to the pandemic but in all the many dferent walks of le in which we provide first aid and other services to our communities. She appealed to anyone considering using their free time to help others to come forward.  We can never have enough volunteers and I would encourage anybody who has been inspired by recent events to help their community, to speak to St John Ambulance and find out more about the opportunities available, she said. Volunteers at St John can be part of the team that saves lives, whether itaposs helping people in the community, providing first aid at events or supporting the NHS.It comes after the Countess backed the Mirroraposs campaign to make the internet safe for children amid growing concern for young people being groomed, bullied and exploited online. To coincide with our call launched last week Sophie did an exclusive article warning how the internet has become a dangerous wild west for children. The countess says the pandemic has created a “perfect storm of risks, leaving children exposed to abusers who target those who might be feeling lonely and isolated.” The Mirror is calling for the Online Safety Bill to be strengthened so there is more protection for children.We also want more help for parents so they can help their kids navigate the dangers of the internet, tougher penalties for tech firm bosses who fail to prevent grooming and bullying and mandatory classes in schools on internet safety.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sophie WessexNHSRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tinder charging young gay lesbian
story: Lesbian couple sitting in sofa, toasting wine" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-.jpg" width"" "" Some gay and lesbian users were paying moreImage: Getty ImagesByJosie ClarkeGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Dating app Tinder is charging young gay and lesbian users and people over  more for its premium service, an investigation claims to have discovered. Watchdog Which  says their exposé suggests possible discrimination and a breach of UK law.Which  asked almost  mystery shoppers to create real profiles and note the prices quoted by Tinder Plus, a premium package . The premium package features perks such as unlimited Likes and Rewinds and the ability to undo accidental selections. The research showed some gay and lesbian users were paying more, with an average premium of more than %compared to bisexual users, and more than %compared to heterosexual users.Do you use Tinder  Join the discussion in the comment section This trend was driven by the youngest age group, with Which  finding that gay and lesbian people aged  to  paid £. on average - % more than heterosexual users aged under and % more than bisexual users under  . When it came to age, those in the  to -year-old age bracket paid % more - a £ dference - and the over s paid % more - a £. dference - on average for a -month Tinder Plus subscription. Across the entire mystery shopping exercise, quotes for a yearaposs access to Tinder Plus ranged from £. to £., with  dferent prices quoted in total. The watchdog said Tinder did not make clear the full extent of how it applied personalised pricing on the app, with no explanation to customers that their personal data could be exploited in this way.  Which  said it had reported its findings to the Equality and Human Rights Commissionand the Information Commissioneraposs Officeand called on them to investigate whether there had been a breach of UK law. The Equality Act  makes it unlawful to charge people of one sexual orientation more than others unless there is a clear justication for this. Tinder said it was categorically untrue that our pricing structure discriminates in any way by sexual preference. It told Which  that older people did have to pay more in some countries, but said the price dference was a discount for younger users. Which  said this was not made clear to people using the app. The consumer group noted that it was occasionally justiable under UK law to offer age-based price iations for the same product or service, such as discounts to over-s or students, where it can be shown there is a legitimate basis for this. However, it said that in the case of Tinder it was unclear as to why over-s were paying more. Tinderaposs terms of use and privacy policy did not make users aware of such vastly dferent pricing, instead referring only to processing inidualsapos data to deliver and improve its services, to help keep users safe and to provide them with advertising that may be of interest. Tinder is owned by the Texas-based Match Group and made US . billion in global revenue in . Which  director of policy and advocacy, Rocio Concha, said: Our research uncovered concerning evidence that people using Tinder could unknowingly be facing higher charges because of their sexual orientation and age. This suggests possible unlawful price discrimination, whether or not it is intentional on Tinderaposs part, and potentially unlawful processing of personal data. We are calling for the EHRC and the ICO to investigate this issue further. If regulators decide that Tinderaposs personalised pricing is breaking the law, then the dating app giant must face strong action. A Tinder spokeswoman told Which : Tinder is free to use and the vast majority of our members enjoy our app without upgrading to the paid experience. However, we do offer a iety of subscription options to help our members stand out and match with new people more efficiently.  Tinder operates a global business and, in some geographies, we offer discounted subscriptions to younger members. In addition, we frequently offer promotional rates which can y based on factors like location orof subscription. No other demographic information is considered in our pricing structure. The spokeswoman added: It is categorically untrue that our pricing structure discriminates in any way by sexual preference. Any reporting or inference is patently  and outrageous. There are no truths to the Which  mystery shopping activity. An EHRC spokeswoman said: As Britainaposs equality regulator it is our job to protect, uphold and enforce equality laws. We take reports of discrimination very seriously. This report of potential discrimination by Tinder is concerning. We will consider these findings by Which  and respond in due course.
